args:
Determine whether this NHTSA investigation summary is relevant to the Washington Post. Return `{"result": true}` or `{"result": false}`
content: Child seat harness may not restrain occupant in the event of a crash.

On April 18, 2024, the Office of Defects Investigation (ODI) received a Defect Petition requesting the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) investigate the Nuna Rava child seat for a harness that can allegedly loosen without pressing the harness release button. The Petitioner states there are 24 complaints in the NHTSA database all describing a similar issue. According to the Petitioner, "this condition has poor detectability and the consequence of failure in case of a crash would be severe or fatal injury". On April 25, 2024, ODI received a second Defect Petition requesting NHTSA investigate Nuna child seats for a similar allegation as the initial petitioner.  Upon receiving these Defect Petitions, ODI sent an Information Request (IR) letter to Nuna on May 16, 2024, asking for information regarding the petitioners’ allegations.  Nuna requested a two-week extension and responded to ODI’s IR letter on June 21,2024. On July 18, 2024, Nuna submitted a supplemental response to ODI’s IR Letter.After evaluating the petitioner’s allegations and Nuna’s response to ODI’s IR letter, ODI has decided to grant the petition and open this defect investigation.nan

Number of Units Affected: nan
